source.name: Mouse anti-human neutrophil elastase clone ELA10-101.5

source.description:
Supernatant from PMA-stimulated neutrophils will be used as the standard for the MPO-DNA and H3(cit) ELISAs.
Carry out the following to obtain NET-rich supernatant.
Isolating granulocytes:
From a healthy volunteer, draw
into EDTA blood collection tubes.
To two 15 mL centrifuge tubes, add
.
Carefully layer
on top of each Polymorphprep layer.
Centrifuge these tubes
.
  • Following centrifugation, two cell layers will have formed which are distinct from the packed red blood cell fraction. Aspirate of and discard the first cell layer (PBMCs).
  • Carefully aspirate off the remaining granulocyte layer and pool in a 50 mL centrifuge tube and add 1x PBS to
  • .
  • Centrifuge at
  • .
  • Resuspend the granulocyte pellet in
  • . This will lyse any contaminating red blood cells.
  • After
  • , add
  • .
  • Centrifuge at
  • .
  • Resuspend in
  • , count and adjust cell count to 2 x 106 cells/mL. Cell culture media used here: 10% FCS, 2 mM L-glutamate, 100 U/mL penicillin, 100 μg/mL streptomycin, 0.01M HEPES buffer, 0.1% β-mercaptoethanol, 0.01 nM non-essential amino acids.
  • Diluting phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA):
  • PMA is provided as a lyophilized powder that is reconstituted in DMSO. Dilute PMA to a final concentration of
  • using cell culture media. Ensure that the concentration of DMSO does not exceed 0.1% in this solution.
  • PMA stimulation:
  • Add isolated granulocytes with diluted PMA in a 1:1 ratio (50 µL: 50 µL) into wells within a 96-well non-tissue culture treated plate.
  • Incubate for
  • at
  • .
  • After incubation, centrifuge at
  • .
  • Aspirate off the NET-rich supernatant, aliquot and store at
  • until required. Be careful not to disturb the neutrophil monolayer, only collect cell-free supernatant.
  • Repeat:
  • Repeat this protocol for a total of 10 times. Each time, draw blood from a new healthy donor.

source.body: All sample dilutions should be empirically established according to spike-and-recovery and parallelism experiments. Likewise, the concentrations for the standard should be empirically established to ensure saturation and acceptable recovery. We provide these dilutions as a starting point.

For the NE-DNA ELISA, a number of unknown clinical serum samples should be screened to determine a number of samples (preferably > 5) that show the highest level of endogenous NE-DNA complexes.
The NE-DNA ELISA procedure described below can be used to determine these samples.

Preparation and storage of NET standards:
  • For MPO-DNA and H3(cit) ELISAs.
  • For each of 10 healthy volunteers, NET-rich supernatant from PMA-stimulated neutrophils has been aliquoted and stored. Before proceeding with NET ELISAs, thaw an aliquot from each healthy volunteer and pool.
  • Aliquot out pooled NET-rich supernatant in
  • and store at
  • until required.
  • For NE-DNA ELISA.
For each of 10 healthy volunteers, NET-rich supernatant from PMA-stimulated neutrophils has been aliquoted and stored. Before proceeding with NET ELISAs, thaw an aliquot from each healthy volunteer and pool.
Aliquot out pooled NET-rich supernatant in
and store at
until required.
    Having identified a number of clinical serum samples with high endogenous levels of NE-DNA complexes, thaw an aliquot from each sample and pool.
    Aliquot out pooled serum in
    and store at
    until required.

description: This protocol steps through the ELISA procedure for detecting three NET-specific biomarkers: 1) myeloperoxidase-DNA (MPO-DNA) complexes, 2) neutrophil elastase-DNA (NE-DNA) complexes, and 3) citrullinated histone H3 (H3(cit)).
